issue.title: Added OQS-OpenSSH demo
issue.body:
Hi @baentsch and @dstebila

Referring to issue #54. 

As we talked about, we have (the [ISE institute](https://www.fhnw.ch/en/about-fhnw/schools/school-of-engineering/institutes/institute-for-sensors-and-electronics) from [FHNW](https://www.fhnw.ch/en)) have created a docker demo image that uses your OQS-OpenSSH implementation.

The [README.md](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/README.md) contains setup and general information while the [USAGE.md](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/USAGE.md) describes some more advanced use cases, like using this demo to connect to a remote OQS-OpenSSH instance.

I've added a new job for [CircleCI](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/.circleci/config.yml) for this demo image. The test it does is connecting to itself (localhost) using chosen PQC algorithms via OQS-SSH. Defaults are p256-dilithium2 and ecdh-nistp384-kyber-1024, chosen more or less randomly. Those algorithms may be changed by passing the SIG and/or KEM variables to the docker run command.
Return code is 0 if the connection to localhost using the ubkey method was successful, 1 otherwise.

I have **not** added OQS-OpenSSH to the "Push all images" step, I reckoned as you will be hosting the image I'll let you set that up properly.

Git history is squashed down to 1 commit, I do not want to bring my mess over :-)

Let me know if any adjustments are required.

comment.body:
Things look seriously improved, incl. covering lots of possible problems. Very nice.

> I still had the purpose of the USAGE.md and README.md files confused

I tend to agree: `README.md` still contains quite a bit of usage information, e.g., the whole "### Connect from container to container via OQS-SSH" section: In my eyes, a person only doing `docker run` (say, off docker hub) should understand anything s/he can do by reading `USAGE.md` (from quick start to advanced usage). `README.md` should (only) explain all build options (and point to `USAGE.md` as/where appropriate).

From the contents perspective, I'd kind of prefer a stronger algorithm than dilithium2-hybrid as default.

Nit-picks: Some files git complains about as not containing a final newline.

>  @baentsch take a final look

Will do that once the docs are truly final. My test will be going through everything both as a user & builder and expect all sample steps to work (possibly trying some alternatives, too :-). @xykro please tag me when this is done:

> Will clean that up and follow up with one last commit

issue.body:
Hi @baentsch and @dstebila

As we talked about, we have (the [ISE institute](https://www.fhnw.ch/en/about-fhnw/schools/school-of-engineering/institutes/institute-for-sensors-and-electronics) from [FHNW](https://www.fhnw.ch/en)) have created a docker demo image that uses your OQS-OpenSSH implementation.

The [README.md](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/README.md) contains setup and general information while the [USAGE.md](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/USAGE.md) describes some more advanced use cases, like using this demo to connect to a remote OQS-OpenSSH instance.

I've added a new job for [CircleCI](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/.circleci/config.yml) for this demo image. The test it does is connecting to itself (localhost) using chosen PQC algorithms via OQS-SSH. Defaults are p256-dilithium2 and ecdh-nistp384-kyber-1024, chosen more or less randomly. Those algorithms may be changed by passing the SIG and/or KEM variables to the docker run command.
Return code is 0 if the connection to localhost using the ubkey method was successful, 1 otherwise.

I have **not** added OQS-OpenSSH to the "Push all images" step, I reckoned as you will be hosting the image I'll let you set that up properly.

Git history is squashed down to 1 commit, I do not want to bring my mess over :-)

Let me know if any adjustments are required.

comment.body:
Thank you guys for your time reviewing my work. And forgive me in case I'm using the Github-PR-Tool in unusual ways, it's my first time doing a PR and sometimes I am a bit confused between commenting/responding/reviewing and so on. So many features! ðŸ˜„ 

---
> I followed the instructions (from the [quick start]( docker exec -ti oqs-openssh-client ssh oqs@oqs-openssh-server) and [connect](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/README.md#connect-from-container-to-container-via-oqs-ssh) readme sections) trying to create the client and server images, but the client exits after creating keys. I got it to work last time, but not this time.

@christianpaquin I agree, there was something messed up. Clarified this one.

---
> I tend to agree: `README.md` still contains quite a bit of usage information, e.g., the whole "### Connect from container to container via OQS-SSH" section: In my eyes, a person only doing `docker run` (say, off docker hub) should understand anything s/he can do by reading `USAGE.md` (from quick start to advanced usage). `README.md` should (only) explain all build options (and point to `USAGE.md` as/where appropriate).

@baentsch I think now I am at a point where I can clearly see each files purpose. Thus far it was kind of foggy in my perception. Will address this and planning on commiting later today.

---
> From the contents perspective, I'd kind of prefer a stronger algorithm than dilithium2-hybrid as default.

@baentsch In the [OQS-OpenSSH-Repository, tag OQS-OpenSSH-snapshot-2020-08](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh/tree/OQS-OpenSSH-snapshot-2020-08#digital-signature) (which I am using in this docker build), it is stated that, and I quote "only L1 signature and all Rainbow variants are enabled by default". Enabling more algorithms is a more complicated process (which I will mention in my updated README) that requieres adjusting some files after pulling the repo and is so far not supported in the build process. And I don't want to use Rainbows because they are slow as heck and annoying when trying and using the image. Additionally I reckon, that if only those algorithms are enabled by default there may be some reason behind it?

---
> @xykro please tag me when this is done.

@baentsch Will do.

---
One more thing: @baentsch would you quickly review the `.circleci/config.yml` file and check if my configuration for openssh looks like it should in order to work properly? Let me know if anything needs improvement there.

issue.title: Rainbow V crashes on Windows
issue.body: Crashes on all language wrappers (c++/go/python), e.g. https://ci.appveyor.com/project/vsoftco/liboqs-python Most likely another stack issue...

comment.body:
@baentsch, @christianpaquin new commit is here!

I changed the structure of README.md and USAGE.md quite substantially, moved a lot of content from README to USAGE and added some additional references back to the README and building the image yourself.

Additionally, I streamlined the key-generation process, so that the requirements for ssh_config and sshd_config are somewhat similar in structure to get the keys one wants. Some new, much more detailed information about the configuration is also available.

And there are some more minor changes I can't remember in detail.

And the best for last: We have got newlines at the end of every file now! ðŸ¥³ 

Let me know what you think!

comment.body:
> only L1 signature and all Rainbow variants are enabled by default 

Kind of -- only "asterisk'd algs" are (recent change in doc). But you're right: L2's are not enabled by default. My mistake - I was only driven by the wish for "the middle ground" (NIST level 3 :-) Not an (easy) option, you're right -- maybe an issue for a next iteration. So disregard my comment.

> would you quickly review the .circleci/config.yml file and check if my configuration for openssh looks like it should in order to work properly

Sorry I see this only now that you're obviously already running CI --successfully: So I guess I can consider this moot and proceed with final review/trying things out (first thing tomorrow)?

issue.title: Boringssl Test on lsquic
issue.body:
Hello, I found a quic implementation in C that uses boringssl for the transport layer. I thought swapping the SSL layer with oqs-boringssl will allow for post-quantum certs to work. I am not sure if there is an issue with my certificate generation but I get this error when I try to establish a connection with post-quantum certificates.
 SSL_CTX_use_PrivateKey_file failed

comment.body: Hi @prchander, sorry for the delay in getting back to you, but would it at all be possible to upload the image on Docker Hub?

issue.title: Added OQS-OpenSSH demo
issue.body:
Hi @baentsch and @dstebila

Referring to issue #54. 

As we talked about, we have (the [ISE institute](https://www.fhnw.ch/en/about-fhnw/schools/school-of-engineering/institutes/institute-for-sensors-and-electronics) from [FHNW](https://www.fhnw.ch/en)) have created a docker demo image that uses your OQS-OpenSSH implementation.

The [README.md](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/README.md) contains setup and general information while the [USAGE.md](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/openssh/USAGE.md) describes some more advanced use cases, like using this demo to connect to a remote OQS-OpenSSH instance.

I've added a new job for [CircleCI](https://github.com/fhnw-ise-qcrypt/oqs-demos/blob/pull-request/.circleci/config.yml) for this demo image. The test it does is connecting to itself (localhost) using chosen PQC algorithms via OQS-SSH. Defaults are p256-dilithium2 and ecdh-nistp384-kyber-1024, chosen more or less randomly. Those algorithms may be changed by passing the SIG and/or KEM variables to the docker run command.
Return code is 0 if the connection to localhost using the ubkey method was successful, 1 otherwise.

I have **not** added OQS-OpenSSH to the "Push all images" step, I reckoned as you will be hosting the image I'll let you set that up properly.

comment.body:
> Kind of -- only "asterisk'd algs" are (recent change in doc). But you're right: L2's are not enabled by default. My mistake - I was only driven by the wish for "the middle ground" (NIST level 3 :-) Not an (easy) option, you're right -- maybe an issue for a next iteration. So disregard my comment.

Yes, I saw that they are "asterisk'd" now. Maybe I will automate enabling the other algorithms when benchmarking the ssh connections. Until then, it's L1 algorithms only so far. Even though I'd like to have L3 enabled as well.

> Sorry I see this only now that you're obviously already running CI --successfully: So I guess I can consider this moot and proceed with final review/trying things out (first thing tomorrow)?

I know that CI tests are running and passing, what I don't know is whether pushing the image will work. But I guess we'll see about that. That said: Yes, you may proceed :)

issue.title: Update to upstream master
issue.body:
Followed procedure in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/wiki/Merge-instructions

Also removed last internal openssl crypto references
Also activated testing for all KEM algs.

- [x] tests are added or updated

comment.body:
I've compiled the branch. I get an error when I tried to test the TLS connection: both s_server and s_client complained about the `-groups` argument:
```
/opt/ossl3/bin/openssl s_server -cert rsa2048.crt -key rsa2048.key -www -tls1_3 -groups kyber768
```
results in:
```
Error with command: "-groups kyber768"
```

I didn't have time to debug the program; I'll look at that tomorrow.
